resources.string: Move the tiles into the blank space to make the pattern shown above, by tapping on the tile you want to move.
The 8-Puzzle was invented by Noyes Palmer Chapman around 1874. It was originally a 4-by-4 grid, and called the 15-Puzzle. This is a simplified 3-by-3 version.
Fill in the numbers to solve, leaving the empty space blank.

The solver finds the minimum number of moves to solve a random input puzzle, using the A* graph searching algorithm, which uses heuristics to guide its search. 

The heuristic function in this algorithm uses the sum of the manhattan distance (sum of the absolute differences of the coordinates of each tile compared to each tile on the solved puzzle) and the number of moves made so far. Intuitively, a move that results in a puzzle with tiles closer to the solved puzzle, and that reaches this state with the least number of moves is the best one. 

The algorithm is implemented using a priority queue with search nodes containing a single puzzle state, a priority, and the previous search node. At each step, all possible nodes containing adjacent puzzle instances are added, and the one with lowest priority is polled. Once the solved puzzle is reached, the steps are retraced by calling the previous node of each search node.
